choices.text: Alcohol
Early age of first live childbirth
Early menarche
Nulliparity

questions.text: Which out of these is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early age of first live child birth.

 

Option B:

 

Early age of first live childbirth an early age at first full-term pregnancy is generally considered a protective factor against breast cancer. This protection may be due to hormonal changes that occur during pregnancy that have a long-term effect on the cells in the breast. Having the first child after 35 years of age (late parity) is a risk factor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alcohol. Alcohol consumption is a well-established risk factor for the development of breast cancer. The risk increases with the amount of alcohol consumed, and this association is thought to be due to alcohol's effects on estrogen and other hormonal levels, as well as its ability to damage DNA in cells.

 

Option C: Early menarche. Early onset of menstruation (menarche) is a risk factor for breast cancer. The earlier a woman begins menstruating, the longer her breast tissue is exposed to estrogen, which can promote the growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D: Nulliparity. Nulliparity, or never having given birth to a child, is also a recognized risk factor for breast cancer. This is thought to be due to the absence of the protective hormonal changes that occur during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protective factors for carcinoma breast:

 

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors

 

Risk factors for breast carcinoma:

 

  • Age: incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Personal history and family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz - Jeghers syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hypercarotenemia is the risk factor)
    • Early menarche (<12 years)
    • Late gmenopause (> 55 years)
    • First full-term pregnancy >35 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (Postmenopausal)
    • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake, chest wall radiation
  • OCPills and smoking have a low risk association

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 931, table 58.3

choices.text: Apocrine metaplasia
Florid hyperplasia
Atypical hyperplasia
LCIS

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pre malignant lesion associated with breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apocrine metaplasia

 

Option A:

 

Apocrine metaplasia is seen in breast cysts and is always benign.

 

Apocrine Metaplasia is a benign change in the breast where ductal epithelial cells transform into cells resembling those of the apocrine glands. It is often found in fibrocystic changes and is not associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Florid Hyperplasia Florid hyperplasia, also known as usual ductal hyperplasia, is an overgrowth of the cells lining the ducts of the breast tissue. While it is not in itself considered premalignant, there is a slight increase in the risk of developing breast cancer compared to the general population, particularly when the hyperplasia is moderate to florid.

 

Option C: Atypical Hyperplasia Atypical hyperplasia is a condition where there is an overgrowth of cells in the breast with some atypical (abnormal) appearance. This includes both atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH). It is a recognized premalignant lesion and is associated with a higher risk of developing breast cancer — approximately four to five times the risk compared to women without these lesions.

 

Option D: LCIS Lobular Carcinoma in Situ (LCIS) is a condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. This is considered a marker for an increased risk of developing breast cancer in either breast and is therefore often categorized as a premalignant lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine metaplasia (Option A) is not a premalignant lesion associated with breast cancer; it is a benign finding commonly seen in breast cysts and does not confer an increased risk for developing breast cancer. Conversely, conditions like florid hyperplasia, atypical hyperplasia, and LCIS are associated with a higher risk and are considered premalignant to varying degrees.

 

No increased risk

 

  • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
  • Apocrine metaplasia
  • Cysts, macro and / or micro
  • Duct ectasia
  • Fibroadenoma
  • Fibrosis
  • Hyperplasia
  • Mastitis (inflammation)
  • Periductal mastitis

 

Slightly increased risk (1.5-2 times)

 

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid, or papillary
  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core (relative risk =3)

 

Moderately increased risk (5 times)

 

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular) (Relative risk = 4 or 5)

 

Insufficient data to assign a risk

 

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
  • Radial scar lesion

 

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -27th edition page no 871

28th Ed. Table 58.3

choices.text: BRCA1 is associated with 50 to 85% lifetime risk of Ca Breast.
BRCA2 is located in chromosome 13.
BRCA1 is mostly associated with triple receptor-negative cancers.
BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about BRCA genes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma.

 

Option D:

 

BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma. This statement is not correct. While mutations in both BRCA1 and BRCA2 can increase the risk of male breast cancer, BRCA2 mutations are more commonly associated with breast cancer in men than BRCA1 mutations.

 

Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

 

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes with Autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric inherited form compared to sporadic cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: BRCA1 is associated with a 50 to 85% lifetime risk of Ca Breast. This statement is correct. Women with mutations in the BRCA1 gene have a significantly increased risk of developing breast cancer, with lifetime risks ranging from 50% to 85%.

 

Option B: BRCA2 is located on chromosome 13. This statement is correct. The BRCA2 gene is indeed located on chromosome 13q.

 

Option C: BRCA1 is mostly associated with triple receptor-negative cancers. This statement is correct. BRCA1 mutations are often associated with breast cancers that are triple-negative, meaning they lack estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2/neu expression.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Schwartz’s principle of surgery-10th edition page no 515

Devita-cancer principle and practice of oncology; 10th edition page no 1109

choices.text: Upper inner quadrant
Lower inner quadrant
Upper outer quadrant
Lower outer quadrant

questions.text: Which quadrant is most commonly involved with breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper outer quadrant

 

Explanation:

 

Upper Outer Quadrant The upper outer quadrant of the breast is the most common site for the occurrence of breast carcinoma. This quadrant contains a greater volume of breast tissue, including a significant portion of the mammary gland, making it more susceptible to the development of cancerous growths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper outer quadrant of the breast is the most common site for the development of breast carcinoma due to the greater volume of breast tissue present in this area (>50% Terminal ductal units).

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 932

choices.text: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments
Obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics
Infiltration of lactiferous duct
Infiltration of subcutaneous veins

questions.text: A woman presents with rapidly progressive breast lump with skin changes as shown. What is the likely pathology responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics

 

Option B:

 

The characteristic Peau d'orange appearance in breast carcinoma is due to specific pathological changes associated with dermal subcutaneous lymphatics obstruction, typically by cancer cells, leading to lymphatic edema. This edema causes the skin to take on a texture reminiscent of an orange peel, with enlarged pores and thickened skin

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Infiltration of Lactiferous Duct While the infiltration of lactiferous ducts can lead to nipple retraction or inversion, it is not the cause of Peau d'orange. Nipple retraction occurs because the ducts shorten as they are invaded by cancer cells, which pulls the nipple inward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange in breast carcinoma is specifically caused by the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics, leading to lymphatic edema and the characteristic orange peel-like texture of the skin, an indicator of advanced disease (T4b).

 

Peau D'orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is French for “orange skin”.

 

Other appearances due to local invasion are as follows:

 

  • Infiltration of single cooper's ligaments leads to dimpling of skin while multiple ligaments leads to puckering/wrinkling. Simple maneuvers such as stretching the arms high above the head or tensing the pectoralis muscles may accentuate asymmetries and dimpling.
  • Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction. Note: an inverted nipple can be simply pulled out, however a retracted nipple cannot be pulled out.
  • Cancer-en-cuirasse: in this condition, the skin of the chest is infiltrated with carcinoma and its appearance has been compared to that of a coat. It occurs in local recurrence after mastectomy.

 

Note:

 

  • Peau D'orange indicates skin involvement (T4b) in breast carcinoma.
  • Dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

 

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page 932, Schwartz’s principles of surgery- 10th edition page no 518, Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 849

choices.text: 1,2,4,3
2,1,3,4
3,1,2,4
1,3,2,4

questions.text:
Arrange the following types of carcinomas in the order of best to worse prognosis:

 

  1. Medullary carcinoma
  2. Tubular carcinoma
  3. Invasive ductal carcinoma
  4. Inflammatory carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2,1,3,4

 

Following flowchart depicts the order of prognosis from best to worst.

 

 

Order of other breast carcinomas from worst to best prognosis:

 

  • Inflammatory carcinoma breast (worst prognosis)
  • Invasive ductal carcinoma
  • Invasive lobular carcinoma
  • Medullary carcinoma
  • Colloid carcinoma
  • Papillary carcinoma
  • Cribriform carcinoma
  • Adenoid cystic
  • Tubular carcinoma (Best prognosis)

 

Ref: Schwartz’s principles of surgery -10th edition page no. 521 and 522

choices.text: MRM in node negative patients
MRM in node positive patients
BCT in node negative patients
BCT in node positive patients

questions.text: In which of the given cases is this procedure usually performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCT in node negative patients

 

Option C:

 

The following image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera.

 

BCT in Node-Negative Patients Breast-conserving therapy (BCT) in node-negative patients is the typical indication for SLNB. The procedure is used to assess whether breast cancer has spread to the sentinel node, which is the first lymph node to which cancer cells are likely to spread from the primary tumor. If the sentinel node is free of cancer, it suggests that the other nodes are also likely to be cancer-free, potentially obviating the need for full axillary lymph node dissection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A and B: MRM: Axillary lymph node dissection is usually performed as part of the surgical treatment rather than SLNB in all cases of MRM.

 

Option D: BCT in Node-Positive Patients In node-positive patients, BCT would include an axillary lymph node dissection to address the known nodal involvement, rather than just an SLNB, because the presence of cancer cells in the lymph nodes is already confirmed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most commonly performed as part of breast-conserving therapy in patients with no clinical evidence of lymph node involvement (node-negative) to determine the presence of metastatic cancer cells in the sentinel lymph node.

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy:

 

  • First performed by Dr. Cabana for penile carcinoma
  • Sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node
  • Only done on node-negative tumors as a part of BCS/BCT. In node positive patients, BCT includes axillary lymph node clearance directly (without SLNB).
  • In MRM, axillary clearance is done irrespective of clinical nodal status.
  • Technique: methylene blue dye or radioisotope (technetium)-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera).
  • The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed.
  • The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabeled dye.

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s practice of surgery -28th edition page no 936-37.

choices.text: T3
T4a
T4b
T4c

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumor of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Overlying skin shows dimpling. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T staging as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3

 

Explanation:

 

The tumor is of size 6cm. Hence it is stage T3 (>5cm). Fixity to pectoralis major doesn’t affect staging. Skin dimpling is not classified as T4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions.

 

  • Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4.
  • Similarly, involvement of the dermis in the form of dimpling/puckering/retraction of nipple does not qualify as T4.

 

Points to Remember

 

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6*3 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3(>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

 

TNM Staging of carcinoma breast.

 

 

 

#Chest wall includes serratus anterior, intercostal muscles, ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

 

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peau d'orange) involving ≥ 1/3rd of breast.

 

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

 

Ref: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 843 and 844, Schwartz’s principle of surgery -10th edition page no 532, Journal AJCC-2017, Pg 674.

choices.text: T2 N2a M0
T4b N3c M0
T2 N3c M1
T4b N3c M1

questions.text: A patient present with a left breast lump of size 3cm x 4cm. The overlying skin has a ‘orange-like skin’ appearance. On the right side, mobile axillary nodes are palpable. On the left side, supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable. The most appropriate tumor staging is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4b N3c M1

 

Explanation:

 

In the TNM staging system for breast cancer, T refers to the size and extent of the main tumor, N describes the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph node involvement, and M indicates the absence or presence of distant metastases.

 

  • Tumor of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance): T4b
  • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement: N3c
  • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates metastasis in the case of breast carcinoma: M1
  • Therefore, the staging is T4b N3c M1.

choices.text: Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high
Luminal B: ER +, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high
Triple negative: ER/PR -, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high
Her 2 enriched: ER/PR -, Her 2 +, Ki 67 high

questions.text: Identify the mismatch receptor profile of breast cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high

 

Option A:

 

Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high Luminal A breast cancers are typically ER and/or PR positive, HER2 negative, and have a low Ki-67 index, which indicates a lower rate of cell proliferation. This subtype generally has a better prognosis and is more responsive to hormonal therapy. Therefore, the presence of a high Ki-67 labeling index in this option is mismatched with the typical profile of Luminal A.

 

The molecular subtypes of breast cancer are characterized based on the presence or absence of hormone receptors (estrogen and progesterone receptors) and HER2 status, as well as proliferation rates, typically indicated by Ki-67 labeling index. Let's go through each

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Luminal B: ER +, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high. Luminal B cancers are ER-positive and tend to have a higher Ki-67 index than Luminal A, indicating a higher proliferation rate. They can be HER2 negative. This option is a correct match for the Luminal B subtype.

 

Option C: Triple Negative: ER, PR -, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high. Triple-negative breast cancers lack ER, PR, and HER2 expression. They often have a higher Ki-67 index, which is consistent with their more aggressive behavior. This option correctly describes the Triple Negative subtype.

 

Option D: Her 2 enriched: ER/PR -, Her 2 +, Ki 67 high. HER2-enriched cancers are characterized by the absence of hormone receptors (ER and PR negative) and overexpression/amplification of HER2. They often exhibit high Ki-67 levels, which correlates with the aggressive nature of this subtype. This option correctly represents the HER2-enriched subtype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Luminal A breast cancers are typically ER/PR positive, HER2 negative, and have a low Ki-67 index, indicating lower proliferation rates. The presence of a high Ki-67 index in this subtype, as indicated in Option A, is a mismatch.

 

Along with ER, PR, and Her-2, a proliferation index known as ki-67 index is also used. Ki 67 is a nuclear protein associated with cellular proliferation.

 

Molecular classification of cancers:

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 931, Table 58.4

choices.text: The axillary nodes receive approximately 80-85% of the drainage.
The lateral group is located along the axillary vein.
The anterior group is usually the sentinel node for CA breast
Lymph nodes of Rotor belong to level III

questions.text: Given below are 4 statements regarding the lymphatic drainage of the breast. Choose the false statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lymph nodes of Rotor belong to level III.

 

Option D:

 

Lymph nodes of Rotor belong to level III. This statement is false. Rotter's nodes (interpectoral nodes) are located between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, and they are considered part of Level II, not Level III. Level III nodes are those located medial to the pectoralis minor muscle and include the apical group.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The axillary nodes receive approximately 80-85% of the drainage. This statement is true. The axillary lymph nodes are the primary drainage site for the lymphatics of the breast, receiving the majority of the lymphatic flow.

 

Option B: The lateral group is located along the axillary vein. This statement is also true. The lateral group of axillary lymph nodes is found along the axillary vein and is often involved in the lymphatic drainage from the upper limb and breast.

 

Option C: The anterior group is usually the sentinel node for CA breast. This is true. The anterior group of axillary lymph nodes, located along the lateral thoracic vessels, often contains the sentinel lymph node in cases of breast cancer, which is the first node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The false statement regarding the lymphatic drainage of the breast is that Rotter's nodes belong to level III; instead, they are part of Level II axillary nodes, situated between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.

 

Lymph nodes are divided on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor, not the pectoralis major.

 

Lymphatic drainage of breast:

 

The lymphatics of breast drain predominantly into:

 

  • The axillary lymph nodes (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Posterior intercostal/ interpectoral/Rotter’s lymph nodes

 

The axillary nodes are arranged in the following groups:

 

Level I (lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

 

  • Lateral, along the axillary vein-drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group), along the lateral thoracic vessels- drains most of the breast. (1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group), along the subscapular vessels

 

Level II (lymph nodes nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

 

  • Central, embedded in at in the center of the axilla- receive drainage from level I groups
  • Interpectoral (Rotter's node)- a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.

 

Level III (lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

 

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group), which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferent of all the other axillary groups and drains into subclavian lymphatic trunk.

 

Internal mammary nodes drain the posterior one-third of the breast.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 915, Schwartz’s principles of surgery – 10th edition page no 502

choices.text: Used for hormone receptor -negative cancers
Provides risk of recurrence and chemotherapy benefit after surgery
Lower scores predict higher risk of recurrence
Used for lymph node-positive cancers

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the oncotype Dx, a molecular test used for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Provides risk of recurrence and chemotherapy benefit after surgery

 

Option B:

 

The Oncotype DX test is a genomic assay that helps evaluate the likelihood of breast cancer recurrence and the potential benefit of chemotherapy in early-stage breast cancer.

 

This statement is true. Oncotype DX provides a Recurrence Score, which is a numeric value that correlates with the risk of recurrence for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. It also gives information about how much benefit a patient is likely to receive from chemotherapy, helping to guide treatment decisions post-surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Used for hormone receptor-negative cancers. This statement is not true. The Oncotype DX test is specifically used for hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancers.

 

Option C. Lower scores predict higher risk of recurrence. This statement is false. In the Oncotype DX assay, lower scores actually predict a lower risk of recurrence and a lesser benefit from chemotherapy.

 

Option D. Used for lymph node-positive cancers. The initial validation of the Oncotype DX test was for use in lymph node-negative patients. It is not generally used for cancers with high lymph node positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncotype DX test is used to determine the risk of recurrence and potential chemotherapy benefit in early-stage, hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer, with lower scores indicating a lower risk of recurrence and a lesser benefit from chemotherapy.

 

  • Oncotype Dx assay is a molecular test based on the assessment of 21 genes. It is a 21-gene recurrence score assay, in which higher recurrence scores predict increased benefit from chemotherapy. On the other hand, lower scores in this assay predict lesser benefit from chemotherapy and increased benefit from endocrine therapy.
  • It is used for patients with lymph node-negative, ER-positive early breast cancer (Stage 1 or 2).
  • Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy.

 

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer:

 

  • Oncotype Dx
  • MammaPrint
  • Endo Predict PAM50  

 

 

  • Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0-100) is calculated.
  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 940, American joint cancer committee 8th edition Pg 622-623, Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 855.

choices.text: Lumbar vertebrae
Thoracic vertebrae
Femur
Skull

questions.text: The most common site for the hematogenous spread of breast carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbar vertebrae

 

Explanation:

 

Lumbar vertebrae, followed by the femur and thoracic vertebrae, are the most common sites for hematogenous spread of carcinoma breast.

 

They occur via: Breast → Posterior intercostal vein → Bateson’s plexus → Lumbar vertebrae.

 

These bone metastases are more osteolytic than osteoblastic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Most common sites of blood borne metastases (bone) are as follows:

 

  • L= Lumbar vertebrae (due to Bateson’s plexus)
  • F= Femur
  • T= Thoracic vertebrae
  • R= Ribs
  • S= Skull

 

Metastasis to the brain occurs via: Posterior intercostal vein→ Bateson’s plexus→ Dural venous sinus→ Leptomeninges.

 

Note: In prostate cancer, the bone metastases are more osteoblastic than osteolytic.

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -27th edition page no 874, 28th Ed. Pg 932.

choices.text: Tumor is located in multiple quadrants
Patient is not compliant with radiotherapy
Patient has ipsilateral palpable axillary lymph node
Patient has received prior radiotherapy on neck and chest for lymphoma

questions.text: A patient with early breast carcinoma of stage T2 N1 M0 doesn’t want to undergo mastectomy. Which of these is not a contra-indication for breast conservation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient has ipsilateral palpable axillary lymph node

 

Option C:

 

The involvement of axillary lymph nodes alone does not necessarily rule out breast conservation, especially if the lymph node involvement is limited. In this case, up front axillary clearance will be done instead of SLNB.

 

Breast conservation therapy, which typically includes breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy or partial mastectomy) followed by radiation therapy, is a suitable option for many patients with early-stage breast carcinoma, as seen here.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tumor is located in multiple quadrants: This can be a consideration against breast conservation because it may be challenging to achieve clear margins and adequate tumor removal.

 

Option B. Patient is not compliant with radiotherapy: Compliance with radiation therapy is crucial for the success of breast conservation. If a patient is unwilling or unable to comply with the recommended course of radiation therapy, breast conservation may not be the best option.

 

Option D. Patient has received prior radiotherapy on neck and chest for lymphoma: Prior radiation therapy in the region may impact the ability to deliver additional radiation safely. The presence of prior radiation to the chest is contraindication to further radiation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

 

Contraindications for breast conservative surgery.

 

Absolute contraindication:

 

  • Pregnancy, except 3rd trimester
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Positive pathologic margin
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to chest wall
  • Multicentric tumor

 

Relative contraindication:

 

  • Connective tissues disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and scleroderma, excluding rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 935, Schwartz’s principle of surgery 10th edition Pg 538, Devita-cancer principles and practice of oncology: 10th edition pg. 1131

choices.text: Pectoralis major
Axillary lymph nodes
Nipple-areola complex
Pectoral fascia

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not usually removed in modified radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pectoralis major

 

Option A:

 

Modified radical mastectomy (MRM) is a common surgical procedure for breast cancer that involves the removal of the breast tissue, including the nipple-areola complex, and axillary lymph nodes (Level 1 to 3), while preserving the pectoralis major muscle

 

Pectoralis Major in a modified radical mastectomy, the pectoralis major muscle is preserved. This distinguishes MRM from the Halsted’s radical mastectomy, which involves the removal of this muscle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Axillary Lymph Nodes Axillary lymph nodes are typically removed during a modified radical mastectomy. The extent of lymph node removal includes levels I, II, and sometimes III.

 

Option C: Nipple-areola Complex The nipple-areola complex is removed during a modified radical mastectomy to ensure the complete excision of potentially involved ductal tissue that converges towards the nipple.

 

Option D: Pectoral Fascia The pectoral fascia is removed during a modified radical mastectomy to ensure complete removal of breast tissue that may be intimately involved with the fascia overlying the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a modified radical mastectomy, the pectoralis major muscle is not removed, distinguishing it from the more extensive Halsted’s radical mastectomy.Top of Form

 

Patey’s modified radical mastectomy removes:

 

  • All breast tissue
  • Nipple-areola complex
  • Skin overlying tumor
  • Levels I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes.
  • Pectoralis minor.

 

Scanlon’s modification of MRM: Pectoralis minor is cut, then sutured back

 

Auchincloss’ modification of MRM: Pectoralis minor is retracted only.

 

Important surgeries for breast cancer:

 

  • Lumpectomy/Wide local excision: Excision of lump with 1 cm gross margin.
  • Simple mastectomy: Entire breast + Nipple – areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin (inframammary incision). Done for gynacomastia
  • Modified radical mastectomy: entire breast tissue + NAC + lymph nodes (levels I + II + III)
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple- areola complex + skin +levels I + II + III axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg Table 58.4, Schwartz’s principles of surgery -10th edition page no 547

choices.text: Seroma
Lymphedema
Intercostobrachial nerve injury
Wound infection

questions.text: The most common complication following mastectomy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seroma

 

Option A:

 

Seromas are collections of fluid that build up under the skin flaps or in the axilla after a mastectomy. They are indeed the most common complication, occurring due to the disruption of lymphatic channels and local inflammatory responses. Seromas can be managed with aspiration and sometimes require repeated interventions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Lymphedema Lymphedema refers to swelling that generally occurs in the arm and is caused by the removal of or damage to axillary lymph nodes during surgery, which results in a blockage in lymphatic drainage. While significant, lymphedema is less common immediately post-operatively compared to seroma formation but can be a chronic issue.

 

Option C: Intercostobrachial Nerve Injury: Injury to the intercostobrachial nerve can occur during mastectomy or axillary dissection, leading to numbness, paresthesia, or pain in the upper arm. It is the most common nerve injury in MRM.

 

Option D: Wound Infection Postoperative wound infections can happen after any surgical procedure, including mastectomy. While these are taken very seriously, strict surgical asepsis and the use of prophylactic antibiotics have made them less frequent than seroma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common complication following mastectomy is seroma formation, occurring in up to 30% of cases due to the disruption of lymphatic drainage and local inflammatory responses post-surgery.

 

Seromas beneath the skin flaps or in the axilla represent the most frequent complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. It has been reported to occur in as many as 30% of the cases.

 

Ref: Schwartz’s principles of surgery -10th edition page no 549, Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -27th edition page no 281

choices.text: Intercostobrachial nerve
Long thoracic nerve
Thoracodorsal nerve
Axillary nerve

questions.text: A patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy. Later she complained of loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the right upper arm. The nerve most likely damaged is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

 

Option A:

 

In the context of a modified radical mastectomy and the associated nerve injury.

 

Intercostobrachial Nerve The intercostobrachial nerve, which is the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve, provides sensation to the upper medial aspect of the arm. Injury to this nerve during mastectomy or axillary dissection can lead to loss of sensation in this area, as described in the patient's complaint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Long Thoracic Nerve The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Damage to this nerve would lead to winged scapula but would not cause sensory loss in the upper arm.

 

Option C: Thoracodorsal Nerve The thoracodorsal nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle. Its injury would result in weakness of the arm adduction and internal rotation but not in sensory loss.

 

Option D: Axillary Nerve The axillary nerve provides motor innervation to the deltoid and teres minor muscles and sensory innervation to the regimental badge area (lateral aspect of the shoulder). Damage to this nerve would not present with loss of sensation in the medial upper arm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intercostobrachial nerve, when damaged during a modified radical mastectomy, is likely responsible for the loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the upper arm due to its sensory innervation in that area

 

Structures preserved in MRM:

 

  1. Axillary vein
  2. Bell’s nerve to serratus anterior
  3. Cephalic vein
  4. Dorsal/thoracodorsal nerve and pedicle

 

Ref: Sabiston Textbook of surgery 20th edition

choices.text: Deep inferior epigastric perforators flap
Latissimus dorsi musculocutaneous flap
Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap
Anterolateral thigh flap

questions.text: A 40-year-old female underwent modified radical mastectomy for carcinoma of breast. She is desirous of breast reconstruction. Which of these tissue flaps will yield the best outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deep inferior epigastric perforators flap

 

Option A:

 

The DIEP free flap is considered the gold standard for breast reconstruction using autogenous tissue. It involves harvesting skin and fat from the lower abdomen without sacrificing the rectus abdominis muscle, thus preserving abdominal wall integrity and reducing the risk of complications like hernia or muscle weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Latissimus Dorsi Musculocutaneous Flap The pedicled latissimus dorsi flap uses muscle, skin, and fat from the upper back and is tunneled to the mastectomy site to create a new breast mound. It's a reliable flap but is not the gold standard because it can lead to weakness in the back and shoulder.

 

Option C: Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap (TRAM) The TRAM flap uses skin, fat, and a portion of the rectus abdominis muscle from the lower abdomen. It can be pedicled (attached to its original blood supply) or free (detached and reattached to blood vessels at the new site). While it is a commonly used flap, it is not the gold standard due to the risk of abdominal wall weakness.

 

Option D: Anterolateral thigh Flap It's a free flap used for complete breast reconstruction, but is not as common as DIEP flap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gold standard for breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue is the Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforators (DIEP) flap, which uses skin and fat from the lower abdomen without sacrificing the rectus abdominis muscle, thus minimizing the risk of abdominal complications and providing a cosmetically superior result.

 

The gold standard in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue is the deep inferior epigastric perforators (DIEP) flap:

 

  • It is a free flap.
  • Only subcutaneous fat and skin is taken.
  • The rectus abdominus muscle is not removed, and hence, there is no abdominal wall weakness.
  • Cosmetically, it is the best flap, and it has the advantage of giving a “tummy tuck” to the patient as well.

 

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap:

 

  • It can be pedicled TRAM or free TRAM.
  • Either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM).
  • Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.

 

The rectus abdominus muscle is excised, and hence, the procedure leads to abdominal wall weakness (hernias can occur).

 

 

Ref: Bailey & Love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 937-940

Sabiston Textbook of surgery 20th edition page no. 868 and 869

choices.text: Nottingham index
Gail model
Claus model
All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following models of breast cancer are used for prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nottingham Index

 

Option A:

 

The Nottingham Prognostic Index being used for prognostication in diagnosed cases, and the Gail and Claus models utilized for assessing the risk of developing breast cancer.

 

Nottingham Prognostic Index the Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) is a clinical tool used to determine the prognosis of breast cancer. It combines three factors: the size of the tumor, the grade of the tumor, and the number of lymph nodes involved. The NPI helps in stratifying patients into different prognostic groups and aids in making treatment decisions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Gail Model The Gail Model is a risk assessment tool used to estimate a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. It takes into account a woman's personal medical history, her reproductive history, and the history of breast cancer among her first-degree relatives.

 

Option C: Claus Model The Claus Model is another risk assessment model that estimates the probability of developing breast cancer based on family history. It particularly considers the number of affected first- and second-degree relatives and their ages at diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nottingham Prognostic Index, Gail Model, and Claus Model are all related to breast carcinoma, with the Nottingham Prognostic Index being used for prognostication in diagnosed cases, and the Gail and Claus models utilized for assessing the risk of developing breast cancer.

 

The Nottingham Prognostic index segregates the patients into four groups, and is used to predict the 10-year survival. The NPI helps clinicians in formulating treatment plans.

 

Nottingham Prognostic Index = (0.2 x Tumor size in cm) + Grade + Nodes

 

The Gail and Claus models are used to assess the risk of development of breast carcinoma.

 

The Gail model includes the following parameters:

 

  • Number of first-degree relatives with carcinoma breast.
  • Age at first live birth
  • Number of breast biopsies

 

Claus model provides individual estimates of breast cancer risk according to the decade of life based on presence of first- and second- degree relatives with breast cancer and their age at diagnosis.

 

Neither the Gail model nor the Claus model accounts for the risk associated with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes BRCA1 and BRCA2.

 

Van Nuys Prognostic index is used to identify patients with duct carcinoma in situ (DCIS) who do not need radiation therapy.

 

This grading system is based on the following parameters:

 

  • Patient’s age
  • DCIS nuclear grade and presence of micro calcification
  • Size of the lesion
  • Width of the surgical margin

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 942, Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page nos 512, 513 and 536, Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 853.

Online resource https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4473391/

choices.text: Paclitaxel
Cyclophosphamide
Cisplatin
Adriamycin

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents is not commonly used for chemotherapy in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cisplatin

 

Option C:

 

Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent primarily used in the treatment of testicular, ovarian, bladder, GIT and lung cancers. While it can be used in breast cancer, particularly in triple-negative breast cancer, it is not a standard first-line therapy and thus is less commonly used compared to the other agents listed here.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Paclitaxel Paclitaxel is a taxane used commonly in breast cancer treatment. It stabilizes microtubules and prevents cell division, which is effective in treating various types of breast cancer, especially when combined with other chemotherapeutic agents.

 

Option B: Cyclophosphamide Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that is part of many breast cancer chemotherapy regimens. It works by cross-linking DNA and RNA, thereby inhibiting cancer cell growth and multiplication.

 

Option D: Adriamycin (Doxorubicin) Adriamycin, or doxorubicin, is an anthracycline antibiotic commonly used in breast cancer chemotherapy. It intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, leading to DNA damage and apoptosis of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the chemotherapeutic agents listed, cisplatin is not commonly used as a standard first-line therapy for breast cancer, whereas paclitaxel, cyclophosphamide, and Adriamycin are commonly included in breast cancer chemotherapy regimens.

 

  • Present chemotherapy regimen used is ACT, i.e., Adriamycin, Cyclophosphamide, and Taxane (Paclitaxel).
  • 4 cycles of AC followed by 4 cycles of T.
  • Other regimens which are less commonly used currently are as follows:
  • cyclophosphamide (C), methotrexate (M) and 5-fuorouracil (F) (CMF);
  • anthracycline-based regimens: CAF (A, Adriamycin [doxorubicin]), CEF (E, epirubicin);
  • Taxane (docetaxel, paclitaxel)-based regimens.

 

Indications for chemotherapy in carcinoma breast:

 

  • Tumor size of > 1cm
  • Tumor size of >0.5 cm with any of
    • Blood vessel/lymph vessel invasion
    • ER/PR –ve
    • Her -2/neu overexpression
    • High grade
    • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
    • High recurrence score after oncotype Dx
  • Any LN Positive CA breast

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 940, Schwartz’s principle of surgery -10th edition page no 551

choices.text: Tamoxifen is preferred in pre-menopausal women with Ca breast
Letrozole is preferred in post-menopausal women only
Hormone therapy is indicated in ER/PR + tumors only
No benefit in insitu breast malignancy

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding hormonal therapy in the treatment of breast cancer except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No benefit in insitu breast malignancy.

 

Option D:

 

No benefit in insitu breast malignancy. This statement is false. Hormonal therapy has been shown to be beneficial in reducing the risk of progression from in situ breast cancer (non-invasive) to invasive breast cancer, particularly for ER/PR-positive tumors.

 

When considering hormonal therapy in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tamoxifen is preferred in pre-menopausal women with Ca breast. This is true. Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that is commonly used in pre-menopausal women due to its ability to block the effects of estrogen in breast tissue without suppressing ovarian function.

 

Option B: Letrozole is preferred in post-menopausal women only. This is also true. Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, which is particularly effective in post-menopausal women because it blocks the conversion of androgens to estrogens, which is the main source of estrogen in this group since the ovaries have ceased functioning.

 

Option C: Hormone therapy is indicated in ER/PR + tumors only. This is true. Hormone therapies such as tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors are indicated for estrogen receptor (ER) and/or progesterone receptor (PR) positive tumors, as these drugs work by interfering with hormonal signals that can promote cancer growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormonal therapies like tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors are beneficial in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer and can reduce the risk of recurrence and contralateral breast cancer, and they also help prevent the progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma.

 

Aromatase inhibitors:

 

  • Include anastrozole, exemestane, and letrozole.
  • Used for the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

 

Mechanism of action

 

Selective aromatase inhibitors block the conversion of the hormone androstenedione into estrone by inhibition of the aromatase enzyme. This is the main mechanism of production of estrogen in postmenopausal women.

 

The enzyme aromatase is present in adipose tissue, breast tissue, breast tumor cells, and other sites.

 

SERM like tamoxifen are preferred in pre-menopausal women, where AI cannot be used due to their ovarian suppression effect. Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor (ER) modulator that is used for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers.

 

It exhibits selective agonistic and antagonistic activity for ER receptors:

 

  • Agonist activity at uterus, bone, liver, and pituitary
  • Antagonist activity at breast and blood vessels

 

Used for:

 

  • Primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Reducing the risk of carcinoma in contralateral breast’.
  • Reducing the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Dose: 20 mg once daily for 10 years (Earlier 5 years was the duration, but latest guidelines recommend 10 years).

 

Adverse effects:

 

  • Hot flushes, most common adverse effect
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Thromboembolic events
  • Reduced visual acuity, cataract, and retinal deposits

 

Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR- positive cases

 

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma

 

Ref: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 858, Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 941.

choices.text: Herceptin
Palbociclib
Buparlisib
Ipatasertib

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved for metastatic hormone receptor-positive and HER-2 negative breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palbociclib

 

Explanation:

 

Palbocilib is the newest drug approved for metastatic, hormone receptor-positive, HER-2/neu-negative breast cancer.

 

It is used along with fulvestrant, a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD) based on the PALOMA 3 trial.

 

Advances in chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer

Treatment of metastatic breast cancer by targeting PI3k/AKT/m TOR pathways has led to newer chemotherapeutic drugs, which are as follows:

 

Cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitor

 

  • Palbociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole) or SERD (Fulvestrant)
  • Ribociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole)
  • Abemaciclib: Approved for use with SERD (Fulvestrant)

 

MTOR pathway inhibitor

 

  • Everolimus: Approved for treatment of advanced/metastatic hormone receptor-positive, HER-2-negative breast cancer

 

PhophatidyI - inositol 3 kinase (PI3k)

 

  • Buparlisib – Not approved, but trials are underway for treatment of metastatic breast carcinoma

 

AKT (Protein kinase B) inhibitors

 

  • Ipatasertib: Not approved, but found beneficial for metastatic triple-negative breast cancer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palbociclib is the newest drug approved for use in combination with hormonal therapies for the treatment of metastatic hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Table 12.6

Journal: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/treatment-approach-to-metastatic-hormone-receptor-positive-her2-negative-breast-cancer-endocrine-therapy?search=Palbocilib&source=search_result&selectedTitle=4~14&uage_type=default&display_rank=4

choices.text: Tamoxifene
Trastuzumab
Fulvestrant
Palbociclib

questions.text: The chemotherapeutic agent of choice for a patient having breast cancer with the following results of immunohistochemistry (IHC) is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trastuzumab

 

Option B:

 

The given IHC image shows cancer cells positive for HER-2 receptors.

 

  • HER-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and hence, cells with these receptors show dark staining of the membranes.
  • Trastuzumab (Herceptin) is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2. It is effective against the HER2/neu receptor. It is used along with Pertuzumab to treat HER2/neu-positive tumours along with chemotherapy.
  • The cytotoxic agent T-DM1 is used in HER2/neu-positive disease: a chemotherapy agent, emtansine, is conjugated to trastuzumab to allow targeted delivery of the chemotherapy to HER2-positive cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tamoxifen:

 

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is primarily used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
  • It is not the drug of choice for HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option C. Fulvestrant:

 

  • Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen receptor degrader (SERD) and is used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
  • It is not the drug of choice for HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Palbociclib:

 

  • Palbociclib is a cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK4/6) inhibitor and is used in hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer.
  • It is not typically used as a single-agent therapy for HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Note:

 

Hormone receptors - Estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore, ER and PR positive breast cancer cells show dark nuclear staining on IHC.

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 940, Schwartz’s principle of surgery -10th edition page no 535

choices.text: Adjuvant Chemotherapy + radiotherapy
Adjuvant Chemotherapy + radiotherapy + anastrozole + trastuzumab
Adjuvant Chemotherapy + anastrozole
Adjuvant Chemotherapy + radiotherapy + anastrozole

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presents to your OPD with a lump in the left breast in the upper outer quadrant, 6 x 4 cm in size. Tumor shows fixity to Pectoralis Major muscle, but not to chest wall. Axillary examination is normal. You perform MRM, with histopathology report and genetic array showing moderately differentiated ductal CA, lymph nodal metastasis and Luminal A subtype. What further treatment will you advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adjuvant Chemotherapy + radiotherapy + anastrozole

 

Explanation:

 

Given scenario:

 

  • Tumor size 6 x 4 cm implying T3 stage. Fixity to Pectoralis major doesn’t affect the T stage. All tumors of size > 1 cm are given adjuvant chemotherapy.
  • Presence of lymph node metastasis is an indication for adjuvant radiation.
  • Luminal A subtype is ER/PR positive and Her 2 neu negative. Hence, adjuvant hormonal therapy is advised but not Transtuzumab.

 

Radiotherapy in CA breast

 

Radiotherapy is shown to decrease the risk of locoregional and systemic recurrence and improve survival. The indications include:

 

  • Patients with locally advanced breast cancers: T3, T4, N1, N2, N3 disease;
  • Following BCT;
  • After mastectomy if: tumor size ≥5  cm; skin or chest wall involvement; lymphovascular invasion (LVI), grade 3;
  • Axillary lymph node positive for metastasis.
  • In pathologically lymph node-negative tumors, radiotherapy after BCS is given to the breast only as a dose of 45–50.4 Gy (with or without a boost) delivered in 25 fractions or of 40–42.5 Gy delivered in 15 or 16 fractions (hypofractionation).
  • In patients after mastectomy (T3N0M0), chest wall radiotherapy is given if the sentinel lymph nodes are negative.
  • In patients with lymph node-positive disease locoregional radiotherapy is given covering the chest wall, supraclavicular region, internal mammary nodes and the axilla. The axilla should not be irradiated after axillary node dissection as this increases the risk of lymphoedema.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 939-940

choices.text: Given in all cases of breast conservative therapy
If MRM shows axillary lymph nodal metastasis, radiotherapy is given to axilla as well
Adjuvant radiotherapy is shown to reduce the risk of recurrence in LABC

Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation (APBI) is a form of radiation therapy used in breast cancer treatment that targets only the lumpectomy cavity plus a margin around it, rather than the entire breast

questions.text: Which of the following is false about radiotherapy for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) If MRM shows axillary lymph nodal metastasis,

 

Option B.

 

Radiotherapy is given to axilla as well

 

In patients with lymph node-positive disease locoregional radiotherapy is given covering the chest wall, supraclavicular region, internal mammary nodes and the axilla. The axilla should not be irradiated after axillary node dissection as this increases the risk of lymphoedema. Thus, post MRM (which includes axillary dissection), axilla is not given RT.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. All patients with BCS receive radiotherapy. BCS together with radiotherapy is called breast conservation therapy (BCT): BCS + RT = BCT.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy is shown to decrease the risk of locoregional and systemic recurrence and improve survival. The indications include the following:

 

  • Patients with locally advanced breast cancers T3, T4, N1, N2, N3 disease;
  • Following BCS;
  • After mastectomy if:
  • Tumour size ≥5 cm; skin or chest wall involvement; lymphovascular invasion (LVI),     grade 3
  • Axillary lymph node positive for metastasis.

 

Option D: Accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI). APBI is a localized form of radiation delivered after lumpectomy to only the part of the breast where the tumor was removed.

 

Educational objective:

 

American Society for Radiation Oncology ABPI guidelines, 2016:

 

  • women 50 years or older with T1 disease and negative resected margins with a margin width of ≥2 mm, invasive ductal carcinoma, no LVI, ER positive, BRCA negative and sentinel node negative;
  • women 50 years or older with low-risk DCIS (screen detected, low/intermediate nuclear grade, tumour size ≤2.5 cm, negative resected margin widths ≥3 mm).

 

The tumour bed is irradiated along with a narrow rim of surrounding tissue so as to avoid the potentially harmful effects of irradiation on healthy tissue. It is delivered twice daily for 5 days

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 935, 939-940

choices.text: Axillary vein
Thoracodorsal pedicle
Angular vein
Costoclavicular ligament

questions.text: The following image shows the boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection. The inferior boundary marked as ‘A’ denotes:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angular vein

 

Explanation:

 

The space of axillary lymph node dissection is inferiorly bounded by the angular vein (marked as ‘A’).

 

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection are as follows.

 

  • Superior: Axillary vein
  • Lateral: Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial: Costoclavicular ligament (Halsted ligament)
  • Inferior: Angular vein

 

A minimum of 10 lymph nodes are removed during axillary clearance.

 

 

Ref: Journal https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3244245/

choices.text: Annual mammogram
Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months
Yearly bone scans

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman underwent treatment for breast cancer of 1.2 x 1 cm with positive axillary nodes. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. Which investigation will you use for follow-up in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

Option A:

 

The follow-up of breast cancer patients after treatment is crucial for early detection of recurrence and monitoring for any complications of treatment.

 

Annual Mammogram an annual mammogram is the standard follow-up investigation for breast cancer patients. It is used to monitor the treated breast and the contralateral breast for any new findings suggestive of recurrence or a new primary breast cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Regular Checking of Liver Function Tests (LFTs) Once in 6 Months. Routine liver function tests are not standard in the follow-up of breast cancer patients unless there are specific clinical indications or if the patient is experiencing symptoms suggestive of metastatic disease or complications related to systemic therapies.

 

Option C: Follow-up with Tumor Markers Once in 6 Months The use of tumor markers for routine follow-up in asymptomatic patients after primary treatment for breast cancer is not recommended. They have not been shown to provide a survival benefit in this setting.

 

Option D: Yearly Bone Scans Routine bone scans are not indicated for follow-up in asymptomatic breast cancer patients after primary treatment. They are reserved for patients with symptoms or clinical findings that suggest bone metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months after 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

 

Ref: Bailey & Love’s short practice of surgery 27th edition Pg 879
